Award.AwardTitle: WORKSHOP: Refugee Protection Outside of the International Legal Framework: Expanding Cross-National and Cross-Disciplinary Collaborations, Northwestern University, May 15-17, 2014

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Eighty percent of the world's refugees seek asylum in non-democratic states or states that have not signed the 1951 International Convention for the Protection of Refugees and 1967 Protocol, do not have implementing legislation or, if they have such legislation, do not grant refugees rights as defined by the Refugee Convention. A two-day workshop at Northwestern University will engage researchers, practitioners and policy makers about the theoretical and practical issues, the lessons to be learned and the strategies for achieving protection in these states.

The workshop is designed to advance theorizing about the meanings of rules or laws governing refugee status outside of the Refugee Convention framework, address empirical puzzles regarding how refugees and international refugee advocacy networks mobilize international and national law, and identify promising lines of inquiry regarding how national institutions define, mediate and respond to refugee legal concerns. These impacts are central to theory-building concerning legal mobilization and decision making by institutions, and to understanding the conditions under which the refugee status determination process itself structures refugees' lives. The research advanced at the workshop will assist in mapping the future of protection outside strict Refugee Convention parameters, and will inform efforts to provide alternative statuses and processes of protection to refugees who are unable to access national asylum status. The workshop will provide a background study that will lay the foundation for future research in this area. Special attention will be given to methodologies for measuring outcomes and for understanding the effects of decisions not to ratify the Refugee Convention on refugee protection and local integration. Having such knowledge will contribute to United States efforts to provide sustainable solutions for refugees, victims of conflict or natural disaster, and stateless people around the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
80% of the world’s refugees seek asylum in states that are non-democratic or have not signed the 1951 International Convention for the Protection of Refugees and 1967 Protocol, and either do not have implementing legislation or do not grant refugees rights as defined by the Refugee Convention.  In order to develop research questions about these states, Galya Ruffer and Bruce Spencer conducted a workshop, Refugee Protection Outside of the International Legal Framework: Expanding Cross-National and Cross-Disciplinary Collaborations, May 27-28, 2014, supported by the NSF Law and Social Sciences Program. The two-day workshop at Northwestern University’s Center for Forced Migration Studies at the Buffett Institute for Global Studies was designed to promote cross-disciplinary discussion and engage researchers, practitioners and policy makers in the theoretical and practical issues, the lessons to be learned and the strategies for achieving protection in these states.

 

Thirty-five academics and practitioners from 15 countries including the UK, India, Sri Lanka, China, Pakistan, Israel, Switzerland (UNHCR), Serbia, South Africa, Brazil, Canada, Hungary, Turkey, Japan, and the United States came together on Northwestern’s main campus in Evanston, IL. The goals of the workshop were to advance theorizing about the meanings, rules or laws governing refugee status outside of the Refugee Convention framework, address empirical puzzles regarding how refugees and international refugee advocacy networks mobilize international and national law, and identify promising lines of inquiry regarding how national institutions define, mediate and respond to refugee legal concerns. The workshop contributed to theory-building concerning legal mobilization and decision-making by institutions and to understanding the ways in which a refugee status determination (RSD) process affects the lives of refugees. These questions are important because, as refugee crises increase in duration and frequency, there is growing reluctance by states that are party to the Refugee Convention to be held to the letter or spirit of the Convention.

 

The workshop was designed in collaboration with the International Association for the Study of Forced Migration, the Refugee Research Network, the Asian Pacific Refugee Rights Network and the Southern Refugee Legal Aid Network with the intent to expand and broaden our knowledge community. Participating were five (5) graduate students, five (5) legal practitioners and twenty-five (25) academics from a range of disciplines including statistics, political science, sociology, anthropology, history, law and philosophy. Prior to coming together in person, the organizing committee collectively contributed to teasing out the questions and themes for each plenary panel and working group session. The questions and themes were shared with all the participants prior to workshop. This format of engaging participants prior to the workshop proved a success in stimulating discussion. 

 

The design of the workshop sought to raise more questions than we could answer and, through a series of plenary panels and working group sessions, spawn further future research collaborations. The format of the workshop included five plenary panel sessions where participants discussed the historical legacies of refugee reception, alternative legacies forged in post-colonial states, formal RSD processes implemented today, informal processes that often substitute for them, and the methods for studying these issues.
